summary.long: Judges is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: After Joshua’s death the Israelites asked the Lord, “Who will go first to fight the Canaanites for us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord answered, “Judah’s troops will go first. I am about to hand the Canaanites over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Judah said to the tribe of Simeon, “Come with us into the territory given to us when we drew lots, and together we will fight the people of Canaan. Then we’ll go with you into your territory.” So the tribe of Simeon went along with Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah’s troops went into battle, and the Lord handed the Canaanites and Perizzites over to them. They defeated 10,000 men at Bezek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At Bezek they also caught up with Adoni Bezek. They fought him and defeated the Canaanites and Perizzites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoni Bezek fled. Judah’s troops chased him, caught him, and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoni Bezek said, “Seventy kings who had their thumbs and big toes cut off used to pick up food under my table. God has paid me back for what I did to them.” Judah’s troops brought Adoni Bezek to Jerusalem, where he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Judah attacked Jerusalem and captured it. They killed everyone there and set the city on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that, the men of Judah went to fight the Canaanites who lived in the mountains, the Negev, and the foothills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they went to fight the Canaanites who lived at Hebron. (In the past Hebron was called Kiriath Arba.) There they killed Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there Judah’s troops went to fight the people living at Debir. (In the past Debir was called Kiriath Sepher.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Caleb said, “I will give my daughter Achsah as a wife to whoever defeats Kiriath Sepher and captures it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Othniel, son of Caleb’s younger brother Kenaz, captured it. So Caleb gave him his daughter Achsah as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she came to Othniel, she persuaded him to ask her father for a field. When she got down from her donkey, Caleb asked her, “What do you want?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She answered, “Give me a blessing. Since you’ve given me some dry land, also give me some springs.” So Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Moses’ father-in-law, the Kenite, went with the people of Judah from the City of Palms into the desert of Judah. There they lived with the people of Judah in the Negev near Arad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Judah went to fight along with the tribe of Simeon, their close relatives. They defeated the Canaanites who lived in Zephath and claimed it for the Lord by destroying it. So the city was called Hormah [Claimed for Destruction].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah also captured Gaza, Ashkelon, and Ekron with their territories.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was with the men of Judah so that they were able to take possession of the mountains. But they could not force out the people living in the valley who had chariots made of iron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Moses had promised, Hebron was given to Caleb, who forced out the three sons of Anak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Benjamin did not force out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem. The Jebusites still live with the tribe of Benjamin in Jerusalem today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Joseph also went into battle against Bethel, and the Lord was with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sent men to spy on Bethel. (In the past the city was called Luz.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The spies saw a man coming out of the city. They told him, “Show us how we can get into the city, and we’ll treat you kindly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He showed them. So they got into the city and killed everyone there. But they let that man and his whole family go free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man went to the land of the Hittites. There he built a city and called it Luz. The city still has that name today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, the tribe of Manasseh did not force out the people of Beth Shean, Taanach, Dor, Ibleam, and Megiddo or their villages. The Canaanites were determined to live in this land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites were strong enough, they made the Canaanites do forced labor. But they did not force all of them out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Ephraim did not force out the Canaanites who lived in Gezer. So the Canaanites continued to live with them in Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Zebulun did not force out those who lived at Kitron or Nahalol. So the Canaanites continued to live with them and were made to do forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Asher did not force out those who lived at Acco or Sidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphek, or Rehob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the tribe of Asher continued to live with the Canaanites because they did not force them out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Naphtali did not force out those who lived at Beth Shemesh or Beth Anath. So they continued to live with the Canaanites. But the people of Beth Shemesh and Beth Anath were made to do forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Amorites forced the tribe of Dan into the mountains and would not let them come down into the valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Amorites were determined to live at Har Heres, Aijalon, and Shaalbim. But when the tribes of Joseph became stronger, they made the Amorites do forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The territory of the Amorites extended from the Akrabbim Pass—from Selah northward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord went from Gilgal to Bochim. He said, “I brought you out of Egypt into the land that I swore to give to your ancestors. I said, ‘I will never break my promise  to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must never make a treaty with the people who live in this land. You must tear down their altars.’ But you didn’t obey me. What do you think you’re doing?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I have this to say, ‘I will not force them out of your way. They will be like thorns in your sides, and their gods will become a trap for you.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the Messenger of the Lord was saying this to all the people of Israel, they began to cry loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they called that place Bochim [Those Who Cry]. They offered sacrifices there to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Joshua sent the people of Israel home. So each family went to take possession of the territory they had inherited.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people served the Lord throughout Joshua’s lifetime and throughout the lifetimes of the leaders who had outlived him and who had seen all the spectacular works the Lord had done for Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s servant Joshua, son of Nun, died at the age of 110.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was buried at Timnath Heres within the territory he had inherited. This was in the mountains of Ephraim north of Mount Gaash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That whole generation had joined their ancestors in death. So another generation grew up after them. They had no personal experience with the Lord or with what he had done for Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel did what the Lord considered evil. They began to serve other gods—the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites abandoned the Lord God of their ancestors, the God who brought them out of Egypt. They followed the other gods of the people around them. They worshiped these gods, and that made the Lord angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They abandoned the Lord to serve the god Baal and the goddess Astarte.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord became angry with the people of Israel. He handed them over to people who robbed them. He also used their enemies around them to defeat them. They could no longer stand up against their enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the Israelites went to war, the power of the Lord brought disaster on them. This was what the Lord said he would do in an oath. So he made them suffer a great deal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord would send judges  to rescue them from those who robbed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people wouldn’t listen to the judges. The Israelites chased after other gods as though they were prostitutes and worshiped them. They quickly turned from the ways of their ancestors who had obeyed the Lord’s commands. They refused to be like their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Lord appointed judges for the Israelites, he was with each judge. The Lord rescued them from their enemies as long as that judge was alive. The Lord was moved by the groaning of those who were tormented and oppressed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after each judge died, the people went back to their old ways and acted more corruptly than their parents. They followed, served, and worshiped other gods. They never gave up their evil practices and stubborn ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord became angry with Israel. He said, “Because the people of this nation have rejected the promise I gave their ancestors and have not obeyed me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will no longer force out the nations Joshua left behind when he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will test the people of Israel with these nations to see whether or not they will carefully follow the Lord’s ways as their ancestors did.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord let these nations stay. He had not handed them over to Joshua or forced them out quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the nations the Lord left behind to test all the Israelites who had not experienced any war in Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord left them to teach Israel’s descendants about war, at least those who had known nothing about it in the past.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He left the five rulers of the Philistines, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites who lived on Mount Lebanon from Mount Baal Hermon to the border of Hamath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These nations were left to test the Israelites, to find out if they would obey the commands the Lord had given their ancestors through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people of Israel lived among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites allowed their sons and daughters to marry these people. Israel also served their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel did what the Lord considered evil. They forgot the Lord their God and served other gods and goddesses—the Baals and the Asherahs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord became angry with the people of Israel. He used King Cushan Rishathaim of Aram Naharaim to defeat them. So Israel served Cushan Rishathaim for eight years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel cried out to the Lord for help. The Lord sent a savior to rescue them. It was Othniel, son of Caleb’s younger brother Kenaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord’s Spirit came over him, he became the judge of Israel. He went out to war. The Lord handed King Cushan Rishathaim of Aram Naharaim over to him, and Othniel overpowered him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there was finally peace in the land for 40 years. Then Othniel, son of Kenaz, died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again, the people of Israel did what the Lord considered evil. So the Lord made King Eglon of Moab stronger than Israel, because Israel did what the Lord considered evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eglon got the Ammonites and the Amalekites to help him, and they defeated the Israelites and occupied the City of Palms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites served King Eglon of Moab for 18 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the people of Israel cried out to the Lord for help. The Lord sent a savior to rescue them. It was Ehud, a left-handed man from the tribe of Benjamin. (Ehud was the son of Gera.)
The people sent him with their tax payment to King Eglon of Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ehud made a two-edged dagger for himself. He fastened it to his right side under his clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought the tax payment to King Eglon. (Eglon was a very fat man.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ehud had finished delivering the payment, he sent back the men who had carried it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, Ehud turned around at the stone idols near Gilgal and returned to Eglon. He said, “Your Majesty, I have a secret message for you.”
The king replied, “Keep quiet!” Then all his advisers left the room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ehud came up to him as he sat alone in his room on the roof. He said to the king, “I have a message from God for you.” As the king rose from his throne,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ehud reached with his left hand, took the dagger from his right side, and plunged it into Eglon’s belly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the handle went in after the blade. Eglon’s fat covered the blade because Ehud didn’t pull the dagger out. The blade stuck out in back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ehud left the room. (He had closed and locked the doors of the room before he left.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Ehud went out, Eglon’s advisers came in. They were surprised that the doors were locked. “He must be using the toilet,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They waited and waited, but Eglon didn’t open the doors. So they took the key and opened the door. They were shocked to see their ruler lying on the floor, dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they had been waiting, Ehud escaped. He went past the stone idols and escaped to Seirah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he arrived there, he blew a ram’s horn in the mountains of Ephraim to summon the troops. So the troops of Israel came down from the mountains with him, and he led them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He told them, “Follow me! The Lord will hand your enemy Moab over to you.”
They followed him and captured the shallow crossings of the Jordan River that led to Moab and refused to let anyone cross.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time they killed about ten thousand of Moab’s best fighting men. Not one of them escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The power of Moab was crushed by Israel that day. So there was finally peace in the land for 80 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Ehud came Shamgar, son of Anath. He killed 600 Philistines with a sharp stick used for herding oxen. So he, too, rescued Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Ehud died, the people of Israel again did what the Lord considered evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord used King Jabin of Canaan, who ruled at Hazor, to defeat them. The commander of King Jabin’s army was Sisera, who lived at Harosheth Haggoyim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel cried out to the Lord for help. King Jabin had 900 chariots made of iron and had cruelly oppressed Israel for 20 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Deborah, wife of Lappidoth, was a prophet. She was the judge in Israel at that time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She used to sit under the Palm Tree of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the mountains of Ephraim. The people of Israel would come to her for legal decisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Deborah summoned Barak, son of Abinoam, from Kedesh in Naphtali. She told him, “The Lord God of Israel has given you this order: ‘Gather troops on Mount Tabor. Take 10,000 men from Naphtali and Zebulun with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will lead Sisera (the commander of Jabin’s army), his chariots, and troops to you at the Kishon River. I will hand him over to you.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barak said to her, “If you go with me, I’ll go. But if you don’t go with me, I won’t go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Deborah replied, “Certainly, I’ll go with you. But you won’t win any honors for the way you’re going about this, because the Lord will use a woman to defeat Sisera.”
So Deborah started out for Kedesh with Barak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barak called the tribes of Zebulun and Naphtali together at Kedesh. Ten thousand men went to fight under his command. Deborah also went along with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Heber the Kenite had separated from the other Kenites (the descendants of Hobab, Moses’ father-in-law). Heber went as far away as the oak tree at Zaanannim near Kedesh and set up his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The report reached Sisera that Barak, son of Abinoam, had come to fight at Mount Tabor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Sisera summoned all his chariots (900 chariots made of iron) and all his troops from Harosheth Haggoyim to come to the Kishon River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Deborah said to Barak, “Attack! This is the day the Lord will hand Sisera over to you. The Lord will go ahead of you.”
So Barak came down from Mount Tabor with 10,000 men behind him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord threw Sisera, all his chariots, and his whole army into a panic in front of Barak’s deadly assault. Sisera got down from his chariot and fled on foot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barak pursued the chariots and the army to Harosheth Haggoyim. So Sisera’s whole army was killed in combat. Not one man survived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Sisera fled on foot toward the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite. Sisera did this because King Jabin of Hazor and Heber’s family were on peaceful terms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jael came out of her tent, she met Sisera. She told him, “Sir, come in here! Come into my tent. Don’t be afraid.” So he went into her tent, and she hid him under a tent curtain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sisera said to her, “Please give me a little water to drink. I’m thirsty.” But instead she gave him milk to drink and covered him up again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to her, “Stand at the door of the tent. If anyone comes and asks if there has been a man around here, tell them no.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Sisera had fallen sound asleep from exhaustion, Jael, Heber’s wife, took a tent peg and walked quietly toward him with a hammer in her hand. She hammered the tent peg through his temples into the ground. So Sisera died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barak was still pursuing Sisera. When Jael came out of her tent, she met him. She said to him, “Come in! I have something to show you—the man you’ve been looking for.” So Barak went into her tent. He saw Sisera lying there dead with the tent peg through his temples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on that day, God used the people of Israel to crush the power of King Jabin of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites became stronger and stronger until they destroyed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day Deborah and Barak, son of Abinoam, sang this song:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Praise the Lord!
Men in Israel vowed to fight,
and people volunteered for service.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, you kings!
Open your ears, you princes!
I will sing a song to the Lord.
I will make music to the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Lord,
when you went out from Seir,
when you marched from the country of Edom,
the earth quaked,
the sky poured,
the clouds burst,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and the mountains shook
in the presence of the Lord God of Sinai,
in the presence of the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the days of Shamgar, son of Anath,
in the days of Jael,
roads were deserted.
Those who traveled took back roads.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Villages in Israel were deserted—
deserted until I, Deborah, took a stand—
took a stand as a mother of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the people chose new gods,
war broke out inside the city gates.
Not a weapon was seen among 40,000 in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My heart goes out to Israel’s commanders,
to those people who volunteered.
Praise the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You people who ride on brown donkeys,
who sit on saddle blankets,
and who walk on the road—think.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to the voices of those singing at the wells.
Over and over again they repeat
the victories of the Lord,
the victories for his villages in Israel.
Then the Lord’s people went down to the city gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get up! Get up, Deborah!
Get up! Get up and create a song! 
Barak, attack! Take your prisoners, son of Abinoam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then those mighty men who were left came down.
The Lord’s people went into battle for me against the mighty soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who had settled in Amalek’s country
came down from Ephraim.
Benjamin came with its troops
after Ephraim.
Commanders from Machir went into battle.
The officers from Zebulun also went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Issachar’s commanders were with Deborah.
They were also with Barak,
sent into the valley under his command. 
Among Reuben’s divisions important men had second thoughts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why did you sit between the saddlebags?
Was it to listen to the shepherds playing their flutes?
Reuben’s divisions of important men had second thoughts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gilead remained east of the Jordan River.
And Dan … Why did he stay by the ships?
Asher sat on the seashore and remained along the inlets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Zebulun mocked death,
and Naphtali risked his life on the battlefield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Kings came and fought.
Then the kings of Canaan fought.
They fought at Taanach by the waters of Megiddo.
But they didn’t carry off any rich loot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The stars fought from heaven.
They fought against Sisera from their heavenly paths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Kishon River swept them away—
that old river, the Kishon. 
I must march on with strength!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the horses’ hoofs pounded.
The mighty war horses galloped on and on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Curse Meroz!” said the Messenger of the Lord.
“Bitterly curse those who live there!
They did not come to help the Lord,
to help the Lord and his heroes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jael, wife of Heber the Kenite,
should be the most blessed woman,
the most blessed woman living in a tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sisera asked for water.
She gave him milk.
She offered him buttermilk in a royal bowl.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She reached for a tent peg with one hand,
for a workman’s hammer with the other.
She struck Sisera.
She crushed his head.
She shattered and pierced his temples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He sank.
He fell.
He lay between her feet!
He sank.
He fell between her feet.
Where he sank, he fell dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sisera’s mother looked through her window
and cried as she peered through the lattice.
“Why is his chariot taking so long?
Why don’t I hear the clatter of his chariots?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her wisest servants gave her an answer.
But she kept repeating to herself,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They’re really finding and dividing the loot:
A girl or two for each soldier,
colorful clothes for Sisera,
colorful, embroidered clothes,
and two pieces of colorful, embroidered cloth for the neck of the looter.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May all your enemies die like that, O Lord.
But may those who love the Lord
be like the sun when it rises in all its brightness.
So the land had peace for 40 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel did what the Lord considered evil. So the Lord handed them over to Midian for seven years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Midian’s power was too strong for Israel. The Israelites made hiding places in the mountains, caves, and mountain strongholds to protect themselves from Midian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever Israel planted crops, Midian, Amalek, and Kedem came and damaged the crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The enemy used to camp on the land and destroy the crops all the way to Gaza. They left nothing for Israel to live on—not one sheep, cow, or donkey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Like swarms of locusts, they came with their livestock and their tents. They and their camels could not be counted. They came into the land only to ruin it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites became very poor because of Midian and cried out to the Lord for help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Israel cried out to the Lord for help because of what the Midianites had done to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the Lord sent a prophet to them. He said, “This is what the Lord God of Israel says:
I brought you out of Egypt.
I took you away from slavery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I rescued you from the power of the Egyptians
and from the power of those who oppressed you.
I forced people out of your way.
I gave you their land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I said to you, ‘I am the Lord your God.
You must never fear the gods of the Amorites
in whose land you will live.’
But you have not obeyed me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord came and sat under the oak tree in Ophrah that belonged to Joash from Abiezer’s family. Joash’s son Gideon was beating out wheat in a winepress to hide it from the Midianites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord appeared to Gideon and said, “The Lord is with you, brave man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon responded, “Excuse me, sir! But if the Lord is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are all the miracles our ancestors have told us about? Didn’t they say, ‘The Lord brought us out of Egypt?’ But now the Lord has abandoned us and has handed us over to Midian.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord turned to him and said, “You will rescue Israel from Midian with the strength you have. I am sending you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon said to him, “Excuse me, sir! How can I rescue Israel? Look at my whole family. It’s the weakest one in Manasseh. And me? I’m the least important member of my family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord replied, “I will be with you. You will defeat Midian as if it were only one man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon said to him, “If you find me acceptable, give me a sign that it is really you speaking to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t leave until I come back. I want to bring my gift and set it in front of you.”
“I will stay until you come back,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gideon went into his house and prepared a young goat and unleavened bread made with 18 quarts of flour. He put the meat in a basket and the broth in a pot. Then he went out and presented them to the Messenger of the Lord under the oak tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord told him, “Take the meat and the unleavened bread, put them on this rock, and pour the broth over them.” Gideon did so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Messenger of the Lord touched the meat and the bread with the tip of the staff that was in his hand. Fire flared up from the rock and burned the meat and the bread. Then the Messenger of the Lord disappeared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s when Gideon realized that this had been the Messenger of the Lord. So he said, “Lord God! I have seen the Messenger of the Lord face to face.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “Calm down! Don’t be afraid. You will not die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gideon built an altar there to the Lord. He called it The Lord Calms. To this day it is still in Ophrah, which belongs to Abiezer’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same night the Lord said to Gideon, “Take a bull from your father’s herd, a bull that is seven years old. Tear down your father’s altar dedicated to the god Baal and cut down the pole dedicated to the goddess Asherah that is next to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, in the proper way, build an altar to the Lord your God on top of this fortified place. Take this second bull and sacrifice it as a burnt offering on the wood from the Asherah pole that you have cut down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon took ten of his servants and did what the Lord had told him to do. However, he didn’t do anything during the day. He was too afraid of his father’s family and the men of the city, so he did it at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the men of the city got up early in the morning, they saw that the Baal altar had been torn down. The Asherah pole next to it had also been cut down. They saw that the second bull had been sacrificed as a burnt offering on the altar that had been built.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They asked each other, “Who did this?” While they were investigating the matter, someone said, “Gideon, son of Joash, did this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of the city told Joash, “Bring your son out. He must die. He has torn down the Baal altar and cut down the Asherah pole that was beside it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joash said to everyone standing around him, “You’re not going to defend Baal, are you? Do you think you should save him? Whoever defends him will be put to death in the morning. If he’s a god, let him defend himself when someone tears down his altar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that day they nicknamed Gideon “Jerubbaal” [Let Baal Defend Himself], because they said, “When someone tears down Baal’s altar, let Baal defend himself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of Midian, Amalek, and Kedem combined their armies, crossed the Jordan River, and camped in the valley of Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord’s Spirit gave Gideon strength. So Gideon blew the ram’s horn to summon Abiezer’s family to follow him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also sent messengers throughout Manasseh to summon the people to follow him. The tribes of Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali were also summoned to follow him, and they went to meet the enemy in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gideon said to God, “You said that you would rescue Israel through me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll place some wool on the threshing floor. If there is dew on the wool while all the ground is dry, then I’ll know that you will rescue Israel through me, as you said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And that is what happened. The next morning Gideon got up early. He squeezed out a bowl full of water from the wool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gideon said to God, “Don’t be angry with me. But let me ask one more thing. Let me make one more test with the wool. Let the wool be dry while all the ground is covered with dew.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night, God did what Gideon asked. The wool was dry, but all the ground was covered with dew.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jerubbaal (that is, Gideon) and all the troops with him got up early and camped above En Harod. Midian’s camp was north of him at the hill of Moreh in the valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Gideon, “You have too many men with you for me to hand Midian over to you. Israel might brag and say, ‘We saved ourselves.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Announce to the troops, ‘Whoever is scared or frightened should leave Mount Gilead and go back home.’ ” So 22,000 men went back home, and 10,000 were left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Gideon, “There are still too many men. Bring them down to the water, and I will test them for you there. If I say to you, ‘This one will go with you,’ he must go with you. And if I say to you, ‘This one won’t go with you,’ he must not go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gideon took the men down to the water. The Lord said to him, “Separate those who lap water with their tongues like dogs from those who kneel down to drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three hundred men lapped water with their hands to their mouths. All the rest of the men knelt down to drink water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Gideon, “With the 300 men who lapped water I will save you and hand Midian over to you. All the other men should go home.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Gideon sent the other men of Israel home, but the 300 men who stayed kept all the supplies and rams’ horns.
The camp of Midian was below him in the valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night the Lord said to Gideon, “Attack! Go into the camp! I will hand it over to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you’re afraid to go, take your servant Purah to the camp with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to what people are saying. After that, you will have the courage to go into the camp and attack it.”
So Gideon and his servant Purah went to the edge of the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Midian, Amalek, and all of Kedem were spread out in the valley like a swarm of locusts. There were so many camels that they could not be counted. They were as numerous as the grains of sand on the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Gideon got there, he heard a man telling his friend a dream. The man said, “I had a strange dream. There was a loaf of barley bread rolling around in the camp of Midian. When it got to the command post, the loaf of bread hit that tent so hard that the tent collapsed, turned upside down, and fell flat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His friend replied, “That can only be the sword of Gideon, son of Joash, from Israel. God is going to hand Midian and the whole camp over to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Gideon heard the dream and its interpretation, he worshiped the Lord. Then he went back to the camp of Israel and said, “Attack! The Lord will hand Midian’s camp over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon divided the 300 men into three companies. He gave them each rams’ horns and jars with torches inside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Watch me, and do what I do. When I come to the edge of the camp, do exactly as I do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I and those with me blow our rams’ horns, then the rest of you around the camp do the same and shout, ‘For the Lord and for Gideon!’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon and his 100 men came to the edge of the camp. It was the beginning of the midnight watch just at the change of the guards. They blew their rams’ horns and smashed the jars they were holding in their hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The three companies also blew their rams’ horns and broke their jars. They held the torches in their left hands and the rams’ horns in their right hands so that they could blow them. They shouted, “A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While each man kept his position around the camp, everyone in the Midianite camp began to run away, screaming as they fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The 300 men kept on blowing their rams’ horns, and the Lord caused the whole camp of Midian to fight among themselves. They fled as far as Beth Shittah, toward Zererah, and as far as the bank of the stream at Abel Meholah near Tabbath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel were summoned from Naphtali, Asher, and all Manasseh to help pursue the troops of Midian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon also sent messengers to the whole mountain region of Ephraim with this message, “Go into battle against Midian. Capture the watering holes as far as Beth Barah and the Jordan River.” All the men of Ephraim were also summoned to help. They captured the watering holes as far as Beth Barah and the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also captured Oreb and Zeeb, the two Midianite commanders. They killed Oreb at the Rock of Oreb and Zeeb at the Winepress of Zeeb and kept on pursuing Midian. Then they brought the severed heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon on the other side of the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men from Ephraim strongly protested Gideon’s actions. They said, “Why did you do this to us? You didn’t invite us to go fight Midian with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon replied, “I haven’t done anything compared with what you have done. Aren’t the grapes that Ephraim picked after the harvest better than all the grapes in Abiezer’s entire harvest?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God handed Oreb and Zeeb, Midian’s commanders, over to you. What have I done compared with that?” When they heard what Gideon said, they weren’t angry with him anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon and his 300 men headed toward the Jordan River. They were exhausted when they crossed it, but they kept pursuing the enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gideon said to the men of Succoth, “Please give me some food for the men under my command. They’re exhausted, and I’m pursuing King Zebah and King Zalmunna of Midian.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The generals at Succoth replied, “We shouldn’t give your army food. You haven’t captured Zebah and Zalmunna yet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon responded, “Alright, then. When the Lord hands Zebah and Zalmunna over to me, I’ll whip your bodies with thorns and thistles from the desert.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gideon went to Penuel and asked the people there for the same help. But they gave him the same reply that the men of Succoth gave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he told them, “When I come back after my victory, I’ll tear down this tower.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor with an army of about 15,000 men. This was all that was left of Kedem’s entire army. In the battle, 120,000 soldiers died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gideon went up Tent Dwellers Road, east of Nobah and Jogbehah, and defeated the unsuspecting Midianite army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zebah and Zalmunna fled as Gideon pursued them. He captured King Zebah and King Zalmunna of Midian, and the whole Midianite army panicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon, son of Joash, returned from the battle through the Heres Pass
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and captured a young man from Succoth. He questioned him, and the young man wrote down for him the names of the 77 officials and leaders of Succoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon went to the men of Succoth and said, “Here are Zebah and Zalmunna! You insulted me when you said, ‘We shouldn’t give your exhausted men food before you’ve captured Zebah and Zalmunna.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gideon took the leaders of the city and taught them a lesson using thorns and thistles from the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he tore down the tower of Penuel and killed the men of that city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He asked Zebah and Zalmunna, “What kind of men did you kill at Tabor?”
They answered, “They were like you. Each one looked like a king’s son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon replied, “They were my brothers, my mother’s sons. I solemnly swear, as the Lord lives, if you had let them live, I would not have to kill you now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told Jether, his firstborn son, “Get up and kill them!” But Jether didn’t draw his sword. He was afraid because he was only a young man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zebah and Zalmunna said, “Get up and do it yourself! It’s a man’s job!” So Gideon got up and killed them. Then he took the half-moon ornaments that were on their camels’ necks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel said to Gideon, “You, then your son, and then your grandson, must rule us. You rescued us from Midian.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon replied, “I will not rule you nor will my son. The Lord will rule you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gideon said to them, “Do me a favor. Each of you give me the earrings from your loot.” (Their enemies, the Ishmaelites, wore gold earrings.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel answered, “Yes, we’ll give them to you.” So they spread out a coat. Each man took the earrings from his loot and dropped them on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold earrings Gideon had asked for weighed 40 pounds. This did not include the half-moon ornaments, the earrings, the purple clothes worn by the kings of Midian, and the chains from their camels’ necks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gideon used the gold to make an idol  and placed it in his hometown, Ophrah. All Israel chased after it there as though it were a prostitute. It became a trap for Gideon and his family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The power of Midian was crushed by the people of Israel, and Midian never again became a threat. So the land had peace for 40 years during Gideon’s life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jerubbaal, son of Joash, went home to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon had 70 sons because he had many wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His concubine  at Shechem also gave birth to a son. That son was named Abimelech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gideon, son of Joash, died at a very old age. He was buried in the tomb of his father Joash at Ophrah, the city belonging to Abiezer’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Gideon died, the people of Israel chased after other gods—the Baals—as though they were prostitutes. They made Baal Berith their god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites did not remember the Lord their God, who had rescued them from all the enemies around them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they were not kind to the family of Jerubbaal (that is, Gideon) despite all the good he had done for Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech, son of Jerubbaal [Gideon], went to Shechem to see the uncles on his mother’s side of the family. He spoke to them and his mother’s whole family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Please ask all citizens of Shechem, ‘What seems best to you? Do you really want all of Jerubbaal’s 70 sons to rule you or just one man? Remember, I’m your own flesh and blood.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His uncles repeated everything he said to all citizens of Shechem. They were persuaded to follow Abimelech because he was their relative.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they gave him 70 pieces of silver from the temple of Baal Berith. With the silver, Abimelech hired worthless and reckless men to follow him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went to his father’s home in Ophrah. There he executed his 70 brothers, Jerubbaal’s sons. But Jotham, Jerubbaal’s youngest son, survived because he hid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the citizens from Shechem and Beth Millo united. They went to the oak tree that was still standing in Shechem and proclaimed Abimelech king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jotham was told about this, he went to a high spot on Mount Gerizim. He shouted to them, “Listen to me, you citizens of Shechem, so that God might listen to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The trees went to anoint someone to be king over them.
They said to the olive tree,
‘Be our king!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the olive tree responded,
‘Should I stop producing oil,
which people use to honor gods and humans,
in order to rule the trees?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the trees said to the fig tree,
‘You come and be our king!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the fig tree responded,
‘Should I stop producing my good, sweet fruit
in order to rule the trees?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the trees said to the grapevine,
‘You come and be our king!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the grapevine responded,
‘Should I stop producing my wine,
which makes gods and humans happy,
in order to rule the trees?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then all the trees said to the thornbush,
‘You come and be our king!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the thornbush responded to the trees,
‘If you really want to anoint me to be your king,
then come and take shelter in my shade.
But if not, fire will come out of the thornbush
and burn up the cedars of Lebanon.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you acted with sincerity and integrity when you made Abimelech king, be happy. If you treated Jerubbaal and his family well, if you treated him as he deserved, be happy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My father fought for you. He risked his life and rescued you from Midian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But today you have attacked my father’s family. You have executed his 70 sons. You have made Abimelech, who is the son of my father’s slave girl, king over the citizens of Shechem just because he’s your brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So if you are now acting with sincerity and integrity toward Jerubbaal and his family, then be happy with Abimelech and let Abimelech be happy with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if that’s not the case, let fire come out of Abimelech and burn up citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo. Also let fire come out of citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo and burn up Abimelech.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jotham ran away quickly. He went to Beerah and lived there to avoid his brother Abimelech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech ruled Israel for three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God sent an evil spirit to cause problems between Abimelech and citizens of Shechem. So citizens of Shechem turned against Abimelech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God did this so that the bloody violence committed against Jerubbaal’s 70 sons would happen to Abimelech and citizens of Shechem. Citizens of Shechem had helped Abimelech execute his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So citizens of Shechem set ambushes for Abimelech on top of the mountains. They also robbed everyone who passed by them on the road. This was reported to Abimelech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gaal (son of Ebed) and his brothers moved into Shechem. Citizens of Shechem trusted him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went into the country and harvested grapes in the vineyards to make wine. Then they made an offering of praise in the temple of their gods. They ate, drank, and cursed Abimelech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gaal (son of Ebed) said, “Who’s Abimelech, and who are we, the people of Shechem, that we should serve him? Isn’t he Jerubbaal’s son, and isn’t Zebul his officer? Serve the descendants of Hamor, Shechem’s father! Why should we serve Abimelech?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How I wish I controlled these people! Then I’d get rid of Abimelech. I would tell him, ‘Get yourself a big army and come out.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zebul, Shechem’s ruler, heard what Gaal (son of Ebed) had said, and he became angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He secretly sent messengers to Abimelech. “Watch out! Gaal (son of Ebed) and his brothers have come to Shechem. They have turned the city against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and your men must start out tonight. Set an ambush for them in the fields around Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning, when the sun rises, get up quickly and raid the city. When Gaal and his men come out to attack you, do whatever you want to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech and all his troops started out at night. He used four companies to set ambushes around Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gaal (son of Ebed) went out and stood at the entrance to the city. Then Abimelech and his troops rose from their ambush.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Gaal saw the troops, he said to Zebul, “Look, troops are coming down from the mountaintops!”
Zebul replied, “The shadows of the mountains look like men to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gaal spoke again, “No, there are troops coming down from Tabbur Haares. One company is coming along the road by the Fortunetellers’ Tree.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zebul said to him, “Where is your big mouth now? You were the one who said, ‘Who’s Abimelech that we should serve him?’ Aren’t these the troops whose ruler you despised? Now go out and fight him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gaal led citizens of Shechem out to fight Abimelech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech chased Gaal so that he ran away from him. Many were killed at the entrance of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech continued to live at Arumah. Zebul threw Gaal and his brothers out and would not let them live in Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day the people of Shechem went into the fields. Abimelech was told about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he took his troops, divided them into three companies, and set an ambush in the fields. He watched and saw the people coming out of the city. Then he began to attack them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech and his company charged the city and captured its entrance. The other two companies charged at everyone in the fields and attacked them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech attacked the city all day long. He captured the city and killed the people in it. He also tore down the city and scattered salt all over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the citizens of Shechem’s Tower heard about it and went into the basement of the temple of El Berith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abimelech was told that they had gathered there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he and all his men went to Mount Zalmon. Abimelech took an ax, cut some brushwood, and carried it on his shoulder. He told his men, “Hurry and do what you’ve seen me do!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all his troops also cut brushwood and followed Abimelech. They piled the brushwood on top of the basement and set it on fire with the people inside. So all the people in Shechem’s Tower died too. There were about a thousand men and women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelech went to Thebez, camped there, and captured it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, there was a strong tower inside the town. All the men, women, and leaders of the town fled to it. They locked the door behind them and went up on the roof of the tower.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech came to the tower. He began to fight against it and went near the entrance of the tower to burn it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a woman threw a small millstone that hit Abimelech on the head and cracked his skull.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He quickly called his armorbearer. He told him, “Take your sword and kill me! I don’t want anyone to say, ‘A woman killed Abimelech.’ ” His armorbearer did as he said, so Abimelech died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Israel saw that Abimelech was dead, they all went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God paid back Abimelech for the evil he had done to his father when he killed his 70 brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also paid back the men of Shechem for all their evil. So the curse of Jotham, son of Jerubbaal, came true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Abimelech, Tola, who was the son of Puah and grandson of Dodo, came to rescue Israel. Tola was from Issachar and lived in Shamir in the mountains of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He judged Israel for 23 years. Tola died and was buried in Shamir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Tola, Jair from Gilead became a judge. He judged Israel for 22 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jair had 30 sons who rode on 30 donkeys. He also had 30 towns that are still called Havvoth Jair to this day. They are in the region of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jair died and was buried in Kamon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel again did what the Lord considered evil. They began to serve other gods and goddesses—the Baals and the Astartes—and the gods of Aram, Sidon, Moab, Ammon, and the gods of the Philistines. They abandoned the Lord and did not serve him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord became angry with the people of Israel. So he used the Philistines and Ammonites to defeat them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They oppressed and crushed the people of Israel that year. For 18 years they oppressed all who lived east of the Jordan River in the land of the Amorites in Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ammon also crossed the Jordan River to fight the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, and Ephraim. So Israel suffered a great deal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel cried out to the Lord for help. They said, “We have sinned against you. We have abandoned our God and served other gods—the Baals.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to the people of Israel, “When the Egyptians, the Amorites, the Ammonites, the Philistines,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Sidonians, the Amalekites, and the Maonites oppressed you, you cried out to me for help. Didn’t I rescue you from them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you still abandoned me and served other gods. That’s why I won’t rescue you again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cry out for help to the gods you chose. Let them rescue you when you’re in trouble.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel said to the Lord, “We have sinned. Do to us whatever you think is right. But please rescue us today!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they got rid of the foreign gods they had and served the Lord. So the Lord could not bear to have Israel suffer any longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The troops of Ammon were summoned to fight, and they camped at Gilead. The people of Israel also gathered together and camped at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of the people of Gilead said to each other, “Whoever starts the fight against Ammon will rule everyone who lives in Gilead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah was a soldier from the region of Gilead. Jephthah’s father was named Gilead. His mother was a prostitute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gilead’s wife also gave birth to sons. When his wife’s sons grew up, they threw Jephthah out. They told him, “You’ll get no inheritance from our father. You’re the son of that other woman.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah fled from his brothers. He went to live in the land of Tob. Worthless men gathered around Jephthah and went out on raids with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Ammon waged war with Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ammonites attacked Israel, Gilead’s leaders went to get Jephthah from the land of Tob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Jephthah, “Come and be our commander so that we can wage war against Ammon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jephthah replied to Gilead’s leaders, “Don’t you hate me? Didn’t you throw me out of my father’s house? So why are you coming to me now when you’re in trouble?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gilead’s leaders answered Jephthah, “The reason we’ve turned to you now is that we want you to go with us and wage war against Ammon. You will be the ruler of everyone who lives in Gilead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah told them, “If you take me back to fight against Ammonites and the Lord gives them to me, I will be your leader.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gilead’s leaders said to Jephthah, “The Lord is a witness between us. We will certainly do what you say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah went with them, and the people made him their leader and commander. So Jephthah went to Mizpah and repeated all these things in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah sent messengers to the king of Ammon. They asked the king, “Why did you invade my land and wage war against me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Ammon answered Jephthah’s messengers, “When the people of Israel left Egypt, they took my land. It stretched from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River and the Jordan River. Now give it back peacefully.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah again sent messengers to the king of Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “This is what Jephthah says: The people of Israel didn’t take away the land belonging to Moab or Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Israel left Egypt, they went through the desert to the Red Sea and came to Kadesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom. They said, ‘Please let us go through your country.’ But the king of Edom wouldn’t listen to them. They also sent messengers to the king of Moab. But he wouldn’t allow it, either. So the people of Israel remained at Kadesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then they went through the desert, by-passing Edom and Moab. They camped east of Moab—east of the Arnon River. They did not cross the Arnon River because it was Moab’s border.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then the people of Israel sent messengers to King Sihon of the Amorites. Sihon ruled from Heshbon. The people of Israel said to him, ‘Please let us go through your land to our own.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Sihon did not trust the Israelites enough to let them go through his territory. Sihon assembled all his troops. He camped at Jahaz and attacked Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord God of Israel handed Sihon and all his people over to Israel. Israel defeated them and took possession of all the land of the Amorites who lived there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel took all the Amorite territory from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River and from the desert to the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord God of Israel forced the Amorites out of the way of his people Israel. So what right do you have to take it back?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shouldn’t you take possession of what your god Chemosh took for you? Shouldn’t we take everything the Lord our God took for us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You’re not any better than Balak, son of King Zippor of Moab, are you? Did he ever have a case against Israel? Or did he ever fight against Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel has now lived in Heshbon, Aroer, all their villages, and in all the cities along the Arnon River for 300 years. Why didn’t you recapture these cities during that time?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I haven’t sinned against you. But you have done wrong by waging war against me. The Lord is the judge who will decide today whether Israel or Ammon is right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king of Ammon didn’t listen to the message Jephthah sent him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord’s Spirit came over Jephthah. Jephthah went through Gilead, Manasseh, and Mizpah in Gilead to gather an army. From Mizpah in Gilead Jephthah went to attack Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah made a vow to the Lord. He said, “If you will really hand Ammon over to me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then whatever comes out of the doors of my house to meet me when I return safely from Ammon will belong to the Lord. I will sacrifice it as a burnt offering.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jephthah went to fight against Ammon. The Lord handed the people of Ammon over to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He defeated them from Aroer to Minnith and on to Abel Keramim, 20 cities in all. It was a decisive defeat. So the Ammonites were crushed by the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jephthah went to his home in Mizpah, he saw his daughter coming out to meet him. She was dancing with tambourines in her hands. She was his only child. Jephthah had no other sons or daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he saw her, he tore his clothes in grief and said, “Oh no, Daughter! You’ve brought me to my knees! What disaster you’ve brought me! I made a foolish promise to the Lord. Now I can’t break it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to him, “Father, you made a promise to the Lord. Do to me whatever you promised since the Lord has punished your enemy Ammon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said to her father, “Do me a favor. Give me two months for my friends and me to walk in the mountains and mourn that I will never have an opportunity to get married.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go!” he said, and he sent her off for two months. She and her friends went to the mountains, and she cried about never being able to get married.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of those two months she came back to her father. He did to her what he had vowed, and she never had a husband. So the custom began in Israel
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that for four days every year the girls in Israel would go out to sing the praises of the daughter of Jephthah, the man from Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Ephraim were summoned to fight. They crossed the Jordan River to Zaphon. They said to Jephthah, “Why did you fight against Ammon without inviting us to go with you? Now we’re going to burn your house down with you in it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah answered, “My people and I were involved in a legal dispute with Ammon. I asked you for help, but you didn’t rescue me from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I saw that you would not rescue me, I risked my life and went to fight the people of Ammon. The Lord handed them over to me. So why did you come to fight against me today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jephthah gathered all the men of Gilead and fought Ephraim. The men of Gilead defeated Ephraim. They did this because Ephraim had said, “You people from Gilead are nothing but fugitives from Ephraim and Manasseh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Gilead captured the shallow crossings of the Jordan River leading back to Ephraim. Whenever a fugitive from Ephraim said, “Let me cross,” the men of Gilead would ask, “Are you from Ephraim?” If he answered, “No,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they would tell him, “Say the word shibboleth.” If the fugitive would say sibboleth, because he couldn’t pronounce the word correctly, they would grab him and kill him at the shallow crossings of the Jordan River. At that time 42,000 men from Ephraim died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jephthah judged Israel for six years. Then Jephthah of Gilead died and was buried in one of the cities of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Jephthah, Ibzan from Bethlehem judged Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had 30 sons and 30 daughters. His sons and daughters married people from outside their own families. He judged Israel for seven years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ibzan died, he was buried in Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Ibzan, Elon from the tribe of Zebulun judged Israel. He judged Israel for ten years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Elon died, he was buried in Aijalon in the territory of Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Elon, Abdon, son of Hillel, from Pirathon judged Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had 40 sons and 30 grandsons who rode on 70 donkeys. He judged Israel for eight years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abdon died, he was buried in Pirathon, in the territory of Ephraim, in the mountains of Amalek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel again did what the Lord considered evil. So the Lord handed them over to the Philistines for 40 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a man from Zorah named Manoah. Manoah was from the family of Dan. His wife was not able to have children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord appeared to her and said, “You’ve never been able to have a child, but now you will become pregnant and have a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you must be careful. Don’t drink any wine or liquor or eat any unclean  food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You’re going to become pregnant and have a son. You must never cut his hair because the boy will be a Nazirite dedicated to God from birth. He will begin to rescue Israel from the power of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman went to tell her husband. She said, “A man of God came to me. He had a very frightening appearance like the Messenger of God. So I didn’t ask him where he came from, and he didn’t tell me his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told me, ‘You’re going to become pregnant and have a son. So don’t drink any wine or liquor or eat any unclean food because the boy will be a Nazirite dedicated to God from the time he is born until he dies.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Manoah pleaded with the Lord, “Please, Lord, let the man of God you sent come back to us. Let him teach us what we must do for the boy who will be born.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God did what Manoah asked. The Messenger of God came back to his wife while she was sitting out in the fields. But her husband Manoah was not with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman ran quickly to tell her husband. She said, “The man who came to me the other day has just appeared to me again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Manoah immediately followed his wife. When he came to the man, he asked him, “Are you the man who spoke to my wife?”
“Yes,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Manoah asked, “When your words come true, how should the boy live and what should he do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord answered Manoah, “Your wife must be careful to do everything I told her to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She must not eat anything that comes from the grapevines, drink any wine or liquor, or eat any unclean food. She must be careful to do everything I commanded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manoah said to the Messenger of the Lord, “Please stay while we prepare a young goat for you to eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Messenger of the Lord responded, “If I stay here, I will not eat any of your food. But if you make a burnt offering, sacrifice it to the Lord.” (Manoah did not realize that it was the Messenger of the Lord.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Manoah asked the Messenger of the Lord, “What is your name? When your words come true, we will honor you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord asked him, “Why do you ask for my name? It’s a name that works miracles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Manoah took a young goat and a grain offering and sacrificed them to the Lord on a rock he used as an altar. While Manoah and his wife watched, the Lord did something miraculous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the flame went up toward heaven from the altar, the Messenger of the Lord went up in the flame. When Manoah and his wife saw this, they immediately bowed down with their faces touching the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Messenger of the Lord didn’t appear again to Manoah and his wife. Then Manoah knew that this had been the Messenger of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Manoah said to his wife, “We will certainly die because we have seen God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Manoah’s wife replied, “If the Lord wanted to kill us, he would not have accepted our burnt offering and grain offering. He would not have let us see or hear all these things just now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the woman had a son and named him Samson. The boy grew up, and the Lord blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s Spirit began to stir in him while he was at Mahaneh Dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samson went to Timnah, he saw a young Philistine woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went home and told his father and mother, “I’ve seen a Philistine woman at Timnah. Now get her for me so that I can marry her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His father and mother asked him, “Aren’t there any women among our relatives or all our people? Do you have to marry a woman from those godless Philistines?”
But Samson told his father, “Get her for me! She’s the one I want!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His father and mother didn’t know that the Lord was behind this. The Lord was looking for an opportunity to do something to the Philistines. (At that time the Philistines were ruling Israel.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson went with his father and mother to Timnah. When they were coming to the vineyards of Timnah, a young roaring lion met Samson.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s Spirit came over him. With his bare hands, he tore the lion apart as if it were a young goat. He didn’t tell his parents what he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went to talk to the young woman. She was the one he wanted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later he went back to marry her. On his way he left the road to look at the lion he had killed. He saw a swarm of bees and some honey in the lion’s dead body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He scraped the honey into his hands and ate it as he walked along. When he came to his father and mother, he gave them some of the honey to eat. He didn’t tell them he had scraped it out of the lion’s dead body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After his father went to see the woman, Samson threw a party. (This is what young men used to do.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her family saw him, they chose 30 of their friends to be with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samson said to them, “Let me tell you a riddle. If you solve it during the seven days of the party, I’ll give you 30 linen shirts and 30 changes of clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if you can’t solve it, you will give me the same things.”
They responded, “Tell us your riddle! Let’s hear it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Samson said to them,
“From the eater
came something to eat.
From the strong one
came something sweet.”
For three days they couldn’t solve the riddle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourth day they said to Samson’s wife, “Trick your husband into solving the riddle for us. If you don’t, we’ll burn you and your family to death. Did the two of you invite us just to make us poor?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Samson’s wife cried on his shoulder. She said, “You hate me! You don’t really love me! You gave my friends a riddle and didn’t tell me the answer.”
Samson replied, “I haven’t even told my father and mother, so why should I tell you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But she cried on his shoulder for the rest of the seven days of the party. Finally, on the seventh day he told her the answer because she made his life miserable. Then she told her friends the answer to the riddle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So before sundown on the seventh day, the men of the city said to him,
“What is sweeter than honey?
What is stronger than a lion?”
Samson replied,
“If you hadn’t used my cow to plow,
you wouldn’t know my riddle now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord’s Spirit came over him, he went to Ashkelon and killed 30 men there. He took their clothes and gave them to the men who solved the riddle. He was angry, and he went to his father’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson’s wife was given to his best man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Later, during the wheat harvest, Samson went to visit his wife. He took a young goat along for her. He said, “I’m going to sleep with my wife in her bedroom.”
But her father would not let him go in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her father said, “I thought you hated her. So I gave her to your best man. Isn’t her younger sister better looking? Marry her instead!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson said to him, “This time I won’t be guilty when I get even with the Philistines, even though I’m going to do something terrible to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samson caught 300 foxes. He tied them together in pairs by their tails. Then he fastened a torch between their tails.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set the torches on fire and released the foxes in the Philistines’ grain fields. So he set fire to all their grain, whether it was stacked or in the fields. Their olive orchards also caught on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some Philistines asked, “Who did this?”
They were told, “Samson! He’s the son-in-law of the man at Timnah. Samson did it because the man at Timnah took Samson’s wife and gave her to his best man.” So the Philistines burned Samson’s wife and her father to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson said to them, “If that’s how you’re going to act, I’ll get even with you before I stop.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he attacked them violently and slaughtered them. Then he went to live in a cave in the cliff at Etam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines came, camped in Judah, and overran Lehi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men of Judah asked, “Why did you come to fight us?”
The Philistines answered, “We’ve come to tie up Samson and do to him what he did to us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So 3,000 men from Judah went to the cave in the cliff at Etam. They said to Samson, “Don’t you know that the Philistines rule us? Why have you done this to us?”
Samson replied, “I did to them what they did to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the men from Judah told him, “We’ve come to tie you up and hand you over to the Philistines.”
Samson said to them, “Swear to me that you won’t harm me yourselves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “We promise we’ll only tie you up and hand you over to them. We certainly won’t kill you.” So they tied him up with two new ropes and brought him back from the cliff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he came to Lehi, the Philistines met him with shouts of triumph. But the Lord’s Spirit came over him. The ropes on his arms became like strings burned in a fire, and those on his hands snapped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson found the jawbone from a donkey that had just died. He picked it up and killed 1,000 men with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Samson said,
“With a jawbone from a donkey,
I’ve made two piles of them.
With a jawbone from a donkey,
I’ve killed a thousand men.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he finished saying this, he threw the jawbone away. He called that place Ramath Lehi [Jawbone Hill].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson was very thirsty. So he called out to the Lord and said, “You have given me this great victory. But now I’ll die from thirst and fall into the power of godless men.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God split open the hollow place at Lehi, and water gushed out. Samson drank some water. Then he was refreshed and revived. So he called the place En Hakkore [Spring of the One Who Calls Out]. It is still there at Lehi today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson judged Israel for 20 years during the time of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson went to Gaza. There he saw a prostitute and slept with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Gaza were told, “Samson’s here!” So they surrounded the place and waited all night at the city gate to ambush him. They were quiet all night. They thought, “We’ll kill him at dawn.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samson was in bed with the prostitute only until midnight. Then he got up, took hold of the doors, door posts, and bar of the city gate and pulled them out. He carried them on his shoulders to the top of the hill facing Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator
