verses.text: After leaving Gaza, he fell in love with a woman in the Sorek Valley. Her name was Delilah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine rulers came to her and said, “Trick him, and find out what makes him so strong. Find out how we can overpower him. We want to tie him up in order to torture him. Each of us will give you 1,100 pieces of silver.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Delilah said to Samson, “Please tell me what makes you so strong. How can you be tied up so that someone could torture you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson told her, “If someone ties me up with seven new bowstrings that are not dried out, I will be like any other man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine rulers brought her seven new bowstrings that were not dried out. She tied Samson up with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some men were hiding in the bedroom waiting for her to tie him up. Then she said to him, “Samson, the Philistines are attacking!” Samson snapped the bowstrings as a thread snaps when it touches fire. So no one found out why he was so strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Delilah told Samson, “Look, you’re making fun of me by telling me lies. Now, tell me how you can be tied up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson told her, “If someone ties me up tightly with new ropes that have never been used, I will be like any other man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Delilah took some new ropes and tied him up with them. Then she said to him, “Samson, the Philistines are attacking!” Some men were in her bedroom waiting to ambush him. But Samson tore the ropes off his arms as though they were strings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Delilah told Samson, “You’re still making fun of me by telling me lies. Tell me how you can be tied up.”
Samson replied, “Just weave the seven braids of my hair with the other threads in the loom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Delilah tied his braids to the loom shuttle. Then she said to him, “Samson, the Philistines are attacking!” But Samson woke up and tore his braids and the threads out of the loom shuttle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Delilah said to Samson, “How can you say that you love me when your heart isn’t mine? You’ve made fun of me three times now, but you still haven’t told me what makes you so strong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every day she made his life miserable with her questions. She pestered him until he wished he were dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, he told her the truth. He told her, “Because I’m a Nazirite, no one has ever cut the hair on my head. I was dedicated to God before I was born. If my hair is ever shaved off, my strength will leave me. Then I’ll be like any other man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Delilah realized that he had told her everything, she sent a message to the Philistine rulers, “Come here once more.” (She did this because Samson had told her everything.) So the Philistine rulers arrived with the money in their hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Delilah put Samson to sleep on her lap. She called for a man to shave off his seven braids. Then she began to torture him because his strength had left him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “Samson, the Philistines are attacking!” Samson woke up. He thought, “I’ll get out of this as usual and shake myself free.” (He didn’t realize that the Lord had left him.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines grabbed him. They poked out his eyes and took him to the prison in Gaza. They tied him up with double chains and made him grind grain in the mill there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But his hair started to grow back as soon as it was shaved off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, the Philistine rulers gathered together to offer a great sacrifice to their god Dagon and to celebrate. They said, “Our god handed Samson, our enemy, over to us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the people saw him, they praised their god. They said,
“Our god gave our enemy,
destroyer of our land
and killer of so many,
into our very hand!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When all the Philistines were enjoying themselves, they said, “Call Samson in to entertain us.”
Samson was called from the prison, and he made them laugh. They made him stand between two columns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson told the young man who was leading him by the hand, “Let me rest. Let me touch the columns on which the building stands so that I can lean against them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The building was filled with people. All the Philistine rulers were there. On the roof there were about three thousand men and women who watched Samson entertain them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samson called to the Lord, “Almighty Lord, please remember me! God, give me strength just one more time! Let me get even with the Philistines for at least one of my two eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samson felt the two middle columns on which the building stood. With his right hand on one column and his left on the other, he pushed hard against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let me die with the Philistines,” he said. With that, he pushed with all his might, and the building fell on the rulers and everyone in it. So he killed more Philistines when he died than he had when he was alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then his relatives and his father’s whole family went to Gaza. They took Samson and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the tomb of his father Manoah.
Samson had judged Israel for 20 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a man named Micah from the mountain region of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He told his mother, “You were upset about the 1,100 pieces of silver that were taken from you. I even heard you put a curse on them. Here’s the silver. I took it!”
His mother said, “The Lord bless you, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Micah gave the 1,100 pieces of silver back to his mother. Then his mother said, “I dedicate this silver to the Lord for my son’s benefit. I want to make a carved idol and a metal idol. So now I’m giving the silver back to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Micah returned the silver to his mother, she took 200 pieces of the silver and gave it to a silversmith. He made a carved idol and a metal idol. Both were placed in Micah’s home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micah owned a shrine. He also made an ephod  and household idols. He ordained one of his sons to be his priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Israel didn’t have a king. Everyone did whatever he considered right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a young man from Bethlehem in Judah. (Bethlehem belongs to the family of Judah.) He was a Levite but was living in Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This man left Bethlehem in Judah to live wherever he could find a place. He came to Micah’s house in the mountains of Ephraim to carry on his work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Micah asked him, “Where do you come from?”
The man told him, “I’m a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah. I’m going to live wherever I can find a place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Micah told him, “Stay with me! Be a father and a priest to me. I’ll give you ten pieces of silver a year, a set of clothes, and your room and board.”
The Levite accepted the offer
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and agreed to live with Micah. The young man became like one of Micah’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micah ordained the Levite. So the young man became his priest and a part of his family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Micah said, “Now I know that the Lord will be good to me. I have a Levite for my priest.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Israel didn’t have a king. And in those days the tribe of Dan was looking for a place to live. Up to that time they had not received land as an inheritance among the tribes of Israel as they should have.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So all the families of Dan sent out five qualified men from Zorah and Eshtaol. They were sent to spy throughout the land and explore it. They were told, “Go and explore the land!”
They came to Micah’s house in the mountains of Ephraim. They spent the night there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were at Micah’s house, they recognized the young Levite’s voice. So they stopped to ask him, “Who brought you here? What are you doing here? Why are you here?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levite told them what Micah had done for him and added, “Micah hired me, so I became his priest.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “Please find out from God if our journey will be successful.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest told them, “Go in peace. The Lord approves of your journey.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The five men left there and came to the city of Laish. They saw that the people there lived without a care. These people were like the people of Sidon. They were peaceful and secure. There was no one around who threatened to take away their property by force. They were far from the people of Sidon and totally independent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men went back to their relatives in Zorah and Eshtaol. Their relatives asked them, “What did you find?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They replied, “Get up, let’s attack Laish. We saw the land. It’s very good!
“Don’t just sit there! Go at once and take the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you get there, you will come to a secure people. The land is wide open to you. God will hand it over to you. It’s a place where you will have everything you could want.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So 600 men from the tribe of Dan left Zorah and Eshtaol armed for war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They camped at Kiriath Jearim in Judah. This is why the place just west of Kiriath Jearim is still called Mahaneh Dan [The Camp of Dan] today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there they marched to the mountains of Ephraim as far as Micah’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the five men who had gone to spy throughout the land around Laish spoke up. They said to the other men of Dan, “Do you know that there’s an ephod, a carved idol, a metal idol, and household idols in these houses? What do you think we should do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they stopped and entered Micah’s house and greeted the young Levite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The 600 armed men from Dan stood at the entrance to the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The five men who had gone to spy throughout the land went inside. They took the carved idol, the ephod, the household idols, and the metal idol. The priest stood at the entrance to the city with the 600 armed men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When these men entered Micah’s house and took the carved idol, the ephod, the household idols, and the metal idol, the priest asked them, “What are you doing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “Keep quiet! Don’t say a word! Come with us and be our father and priest. Is it better for you to be a priest for one man’s house or for a tribe in Israel and its families?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest was content. He took the ephod, the household idols, and the carved idol and went with the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they left, they put their children, livestock, and property in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had already gone some distance from Micah’s house, Micah’s neighbors were called together to help him catch up to the people of Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shouted at them. But the people of Dan turned around and said to Micah, “What’s your problem? Why did you call your neighbors together to attack us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micah answered, “You’ve taken away the gods I made as well as my priest. What do I have left? How can you say to me, ‘What’s your problem?’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Dan replied, “Don’t make another sound, or some violent men will attack you. Then you and your family will lose your lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Dan went on their way. Micah saw they were stronger than he was, so he turned around and went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Dan took what Micah had made and the man who had become his priest and went to the city of Laish. They attacked a peaceful and secure people, killed them all with swords, and burned their city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no one to rescue them because their city was far from Sidon and totally independent. The city was in the valley that belonged to Beth Rehob. The people of Dan rebuilt the city and lived in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They named the city Dan in honor of their ancestor Dan, Israel’s son. Originally, the city was called Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Dan set up the carved idol for themselves. Jonathan (son of Gershom and grandson of Moses) and his descendants were priests for Dan’s tribe until the people living in that land were taken captive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they set up for themselves the carved idol Micah had made. It stayed there the whole time the house of God was at Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days when Israel didn’t have a king, there was a Levite who lived in a remote area in the mountains of Ephraim. He took a woman from Bethlehem in Judah to be his concubine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But she was unfaithful to him. She left him and went to her father’s home, to Bethlehem in Judah. When she had been there four months,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
her husband went to persuade her to come back home. He took along his servant and two donkeys.
She took her husband into her father’s house. Her father was thrilled to see him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the Levite stay there with him, celebrating for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourth day they got up early in the morning to leave, but the woman’s father told his son-in-law, “Eat something to keep up your strength and then you can go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they both sat down and ate and drank together. The woman’s father said to his son-in-law, “Why don’t you spend the night and enjoy yourself?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Levite started to leave, his father-in-law urged him to stay another night, so he did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the morning of the fifth day, the Levite got up early to leave. The woman’s father said, “Eat something to keep up your strength!” So they spent the time eating until late afternoon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levite started to leave with his concubine and his servant. But his father-in-law said to him, “It’s already evening. Please stay another night. It’s too late to leave now. Stay here, and enjoy yourself. Tomorrow you can start out early to go home.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the Levite refused to spend another night.
He left and traveled as far as Jebus (now called Jerusalem). He had with him two saddled donkeys and his concubine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By the time they were near Jebus, it was very late in the day. The Levite’s servant said to him, “Let’s go spend the night in Jebus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levite told him, “We’ll never go into a city of foreigners. They’re not Israelites. We’ll go on to Gibeah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told his servant, “Let’s go someplace else. We’ll spend the night either at Gibeah or Ramah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went on. It was sunset by the time they arrived at Gibeah. (Gibeah belonged to the tribe of Benjamin.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to spend the night there. The Levite entered Gibeah and sat down in the city square, because no one offered to take them home for the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That evening an old man came into the city from his work in the fields. He was from the mountain region of Ephraim but lived in Gibeah. The other people who lived there were from the tribe of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He saw the traveler in the city square. So the old man asked, “Where do you come from? And where are you going?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levite replied, “We’re on our way from Bethlehem in Judah to a remote area in the mountains of Ephraim. That’s where I’m from. I had gone to Bethlehem in Judah. Now I’m going to the Lord’s house, but no one has offered to take me into his home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have straw and fodder for our donkeys. I even have bread and wine for myself, the woman, and my servant. We have everything we need.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the old man said, “Welcome! Let me take care of your needs. Just don’t spend the night in the city square.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he took the Levite to his house and fed the donkeys. After they washed, they ate and drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were enjoying themselves, some worthless men from the city surrounded the house and pounded on the door. They told the old man, the owner of the house, “Bring out the man who came to your house so that we can have sex with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The owner went out to them. He told them, “No, my friends! Please don’t do anything so evil! This man is a guest in my home. Don’t do such a godless thing!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here, let me bring out my virgin daughter and this man’s concubine. Rape them, and do with them whatever you want. Just don’t do such a godless thing to this man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the men refused to listen to him. So the Levite grabbed his concubine and forced her outside. They had sex with her and abused her all night until morning. They let her go when the sun was coming up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At daybreak, the woman came to the door of the house where her husband was and collapsed. She was still there when it became light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her husband got up in the morning, opened the doors of the house, and was about to leave. His wife (that is, his concubine) was lying at the door of the house with her hands on the doorstep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levite said to her, “Get up! Let’s go!” But she did not answer. So he put her on the donkey and left for home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he arrived home, he got a knife. He took his concubine and cut her limb from limb into 12 pieces. Then he sent the pieces throughout the territories of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone who saw it said, “Never has such a thing happened or been seen from the time the people of Israel came out of Egypt until today. Think about it! Form a plan, and speak out!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and from Gilead came to Mizpah. The congregation stood united in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of all Israel’s tribes took their places in the congregation of God’s people. There were 400,000 foot soldiers with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people of Benjamin heard that Israel had come to Mizpah.
The people of Israel said, “Tell us how such an evil thing could happen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, answered, “My concubine  and I went to Gibeah in Benjamin to spend the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The citizens of Gibeah came to attack me. They surrounded the house where I was staying that night. They intended to kill me, but instead, they raped my concubine until she died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I took my concubine and cut her into pieces. Then I sent the pieces throughout the territory of Israel. I did this because the citizens of Gibeah did this perverted and godless thing in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All you people of Israel, tell me what you think. Give me your advice right now!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people stood united, saying, “None of us will go to his tent or return to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what we’ll do to Gibeah. We’ll decide by lot who should attack it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We’ll take one-tenth  of all the men from the tribes of Israel to get supplies for the troops. When the troops go to Gibeah in the territory of Benjamin they can punish the citizens of Gibeah for the godless thing they did in Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the men of Israel assembled. They stood united against the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribes of Israel sent men throughout the tribe of Benjamin. They asked, “How could such an evil thing happen among you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now hand over those worthless men in Gibeah. We must put them to death to rid ourselves of this kind of evil in Israel.”
But the men of Benjamin refused to listen to the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men of Benjamin went from their towns and assembled at Gibeah to go to war with the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day 26,000 men armed with swords came from Benjamin’s cities and organized for battle along with 700 of Gibeah’s best men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Out of all these troops, the best 700 were left-handed. Each could sling a stone at a hair and not miss.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel (Benjamin not included) totaled 400,000 soldiers armed with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men of Israel went to Bethel. They asked God, “Who will go first to fight Benjamin?”
The Lord answered, “Judah will go first.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites got up early in the morning and camped at Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men of Israel went to war with the men of Benjamin. The Israelites formed their battle line facing Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day the men of Benjamin came out from Gibeah. They slaughtered 22,000 of Israel’s men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Israel’s troops got reinforcements. They formed their battle line where they had formed it on the first day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Israelites went and cried in the presence of the Lord until evening. They asked the Lord, “Should we continue to wage war against our close relatives, the men of Benjamin?”
The Lord answered, “Go fight them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the second day the Israelite troops advanced against Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benjamin went out from Gibeah to meet them. This time they slaughtered 18,000 men from Israel who were armed with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men of Israel and all the troops went to Bethel. They sat there and cried in the presence of the Lord and fasted that day until evening. Then they sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days the ark of God’s promise was at Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
(Phinehas, son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron, served in front of it.) So the people of Israel asked the Lord, “Should we continue to wage war against our close relatives, the men of Benjamin? Or should we stop?”
The Lord answered, “Go! Tomorrow I will hand them over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Israel placed troops in ambush around Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day the men of Israel went to fight the men of Benjamin. They formed their battle line facing Gibeah as they did before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Benjamin went out to attack Israel’s troops and were led away from the city. They started to inflict casualties as before. They killed about 30 men from Israel in the open country and on the roads to Bethel and Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men of Benjamin shouted, “They’re defeated as before!”
But the men of Israel had said, “Let’s flee in order to lead them from the city to the roads.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men of Israel left their positions. They formed their battle line at Baal Tamar. Meanwhile, those waiting in ambush rushed from their position to the west of Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then 10,000 of Israel’s best men attacked Gibeah. The battle was fierce. But Benjamin’s men didn’t realize their own evil was about to overtake them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord defeated them in front of Israel. On that day the Israelites slaughtered 25,100 men from Benjamin who were armed with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the men of Benjamin realized they were defeated.
The Israelites had allowed the men of Benjamin to take back some ground. The Israelites relied on those waiting in ambush near Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men in ambush quickly charged toward Gibeah. They spread out in the city and killed everyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel had arranged with those waiting in ambush that they would make a big column of smoke rise from the city as a signal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the men of Israel would turn around in the battle.
The men of Benjamin had already killed about 30 men of Israel. They even said, “Israel is completely defeated, just like in the first battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the column of smoke started to rise from the city, the men of Benjamin turned around and saw the whole city going up in smoke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Israel turned around, and the men of Benjamin panicked. They realized that their evil had overtaken them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They turned in front of Israel toward the road to the desert. But the battle caught up with the men of Benjamin. Israel slaughtered whoever came out of the cities on the road to the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They closed in on the men of Benjamin and pursued them without stopping. They overtook them east of Gibeah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were 18,000 experienced men from Benjamin who died in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The others turned and fled into the desert to Rimmon Rock. But the men of Israel killed 5,000 more on the roads. They caught up with another 2,000 and killed them near Gidom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all, 25,000 men from Benjamin who were armed with swords were killed that day. They were all experienced men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But 600 men turned and fled into the desert to Rimmon Rock. They stayed at Rimmon Rock for four months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Israel went back to attack the rest of the territory of Benjamin. They killed all the people and cattle they found in every city. They also burned down every city they came to.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel had taken this oath in Mizpah: “None of us will ever let our daughters marry anyone from Benjamin.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people went to Bethel and sat there in the presence of God until evening. They cried very loudly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Lord God of Israel, why has this happened among us? Why should one tribe be missing today in Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day the people got up early. They built an altar there and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people asked, “Is there any family from Israel that did not take part in the assembly in the presence of the Lord?” They had taken a solemn oath that whoever had not come into the presence of the Lord at Mizpah must be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel felt sorry for their close relatives, the men of Benjamin. They said, “Today one tribe has been excluded from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What will we do to provide wives for the men who are left? We swore to the Lord that we would not let any of our daughters marry them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they asked, “Is there any family from Israel that did not come into the presence of the Lord at Mizpah?” No one from Jabesh Gilead had come to the assembly in the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they questioned the people, and there was no one there from Jabesh Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The congregation sent 12,000 soldiers. They ordered them, “Go and kill the people of Jabesh Gilead, including the women and children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are your directions: Claim every female who has gone to bed with a man, and claim every male. Claim them for the Lord by destroying them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Among the people of Jabesh Gilead they found 400 unmarried women who had never gone to bed with a man. They brought them to the camp at Shiloh in Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the whole congregation sent messengers to the men of Benjamin at Rimmon Rock and offered them peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men of Benjamin came back at that time. These men were given the women from Jabesh Gilead who had been kept alive. However, the congregation had not found enough women for all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The congregation felt sorry for the people of Benjamin because the Lord had broken the unity of the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of the congregation asked, “What should we do to provide wives for the men who are left, since the women in Benjamin have been killed?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some said, “Benjamin’s men who survived must be allowed to have families. No tribe of Israel should be wiped out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, we can’t give them any of our daughters as wives. The people of Israel have taken an oath that whoever gives wives to the men of Benjamin is under a curse.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Others said, “Every year the Lord’s festival is held at Shiloh. Shiloh is north of Bethel, east of the highway going from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they told the men of Benjamin, “Hide in the vineyards and
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: watch. When the young women of Shiloh come out to take part in the dances, come out of the vineyards. Each of you catch a woman from Shiloh to be your wife. Then go back to the territory of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When their fathers or brothers come to us to complain, we’ll tell them, ‘Have pity on them, since we didn’t provide a wife for each man in the battle. You won’t be guilty because you didn’t give them the wives yourselves.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Benjamin did just that. They captured the number of wives they needed from the women who were dancing and went home. So they rebuilt their cities and lived in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time the people of Israel left. Each man went to his tribe and family. They all went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Israel didn’t have a king. Everyone did whatever he considered right.
verses.speaker: Narrator
